text: He hath given meat unto them that fear him: he will ever be mindful of his covenant.
text_kjv: He hath given meat unto them that fear him: he will ever be mindful of his covenant.
text_niv: He provides food for those who fear him;he remembers his covenant forever.
text_esv: He provides food for those who fear him; he remembers his covenant forever.
text_nlt: He gives food to those who fear him;he always remembers his covenant.
text_msg: He gave food to those who fear him,He remembered to keep his ancient promise.
text_nasb: He has given food to those who fear Him; He will remember His covenant forever.
context: Psalm 111 is an acrostic psalm, meaning each line begins with a successive letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This literary device aided memorization and emphasized completeness. The psalm celebrates God's attributes and actions, particularly His faithfulness to His covenant. The historical context likely stems from a time of national reflection, perhaps after a significant deliverance or during a period of rebuilding. The concept of 'fear of the Lord' was not simply terror but a deep reverence, respect, and awe-filled recognition of God's power, holiness, and sovereignty. It was the foundation of wisdom and righteous living in ancient Israel. The 'meat' (food/provision) mentioned wasn't limited to literal sustenance; it encompassed all that was needed for life and flourishing, including protection, prosperity, and guidance. The covenant referred to the specific promises God made to Abraham and renewed with subsequent generations, promising land, descendants, and a special relationship. The idea of God 'being mindful' of His covenant highlights His steadfastness and commitment to His promises. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, covenants were serious agreements, and God's covenant with Israel demonstrated His unique relationship with them. Remembering covenants was a frequent theme in the Old Testament, serving as a reminder of God's faithfulness and a call to Israel to uphold their end of the agreement. The repeated emphasis on God's faithfulness would have resonated strongly with the Israelites, particularly during times of hardship, offering hope and assurance of His continued care.
meaning: Psalm 111:5, "He hath given meat unto them that fear him: he will ever be mindful of his covenant," encapsulates the essence of God's benevolent provision and unwavering faithfulness. The 'meat' or provision signifies more than mere physical sustenance; it represents the comprehensive blessings God bestows upon those who reverence Him. This reverence isn't blind obedience but a profound respect and trust rooted in understanding His character. This understanding inspires a life lived in accordance with His will. God's provision is not arbitrary; it is specifically directed towards those who 'fear Him.' This doesn't imply a transactional relationship but rather a natural outflow of God's grace towards those whose hearts are aligned with His. The second part of the verse, 'he will ever be mindful of his covenant,' reinforces God's steadfastness. The covenant represents a sacred agreement, a binding promise that God initiated and maintains. It emphasizes that God's actions are not capricious or subject to change but are grounded in His commitment to His word. The phrase 'ever be mindful' underscores the continuous nature of God's faithfulness. He does not forget His promises, even when circumstances seem to contradict them. This verse speaks to the core of God's character: He is both provider and covenant keeper. He provides for the needs of those who revere Him, and He remains faithful to the promises He has made. This understanding fosters hope and assurance, reminding believers that God's provision and faithfulness are not contingent on their perfect performance but are rooted in His unwavering love and commitment.
application: Psalm 111:5 offers profound practical implications for modern-day believers. Firstly, it challenges us to examine our own 'fear of the Lord.' Is our faith merely a Sunday activity, or does it permeate every aspect of our lives? Do we truly reverence God's authority and seek to live in accordance with His will? A genuine fear of the Lord translates into ethical decision-making, compassionate actions, and a commitment to justice. Secondly, the verse encourages us to trust in God's provision. In a world characterized by uncertainty and economic instability, it's easy to succumb to anxiety and worry. However, Psalm 111:5 reminds us that God is our provider. This doesn't mean we become passive recipients of blessings; rather, we work diligently and wisely, trusting that God will supply our needs. We should actively seek opportunities to use our gifts and talents to contribute to society, knowing that God blesses our efforts. The emphasis on God's covenant faithfulness also encourages us to persevere through difficulties. Life inevitably presents challenges, but we can find solace in the knowledge that God remains true to His promises. We need to anchor ourselves in the truth of God's word, especially during times of discouragement. Moreover, this verse compels us to extend God's provision and faithfulness to others. As recipients of God's grace, we are called to be channels of blessing to those around us. This might involve practical acts of service, financial generosity, or simply offering words of encouragement and support. Ultimately, Psalm 111:5 calls us to live lives of faith, trust, and obedience, knowing that God is both our provider and our covenant keeper.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I thank you for your unwavering faithfulness and your abundant provision. Help me to cultivate a true fear of the Lord, a reverence that guides my thoughts, words, and actions. Forgive me for the times I have doubted your provision or questioned your faithfulness. Remind me of your covenant promises, especially during moments of uncertainty and despair. Grant me the wisdom to discern your will and the courage to follow it. Open my eyes to the needs of those around me, and empower me to be a channel of your blessing. Help me to trust in your timing and your plans, even when I don't understand them. I ask all of this in the name of Jesus Christ, my Lord and Savior. Amen.

faqs.answer: To 'fear the Lord' isn't about being afraid of God but about having a deep reverence, respect, and awe of His power, holiness, and authority. It's acknowledging His sovereignty and living in accordance with His will, leading to wisdom and righteous living.

faqs.answer: The 'meat' refers to more than just physical food. It encompasses all the necessary provisions for life, including sustenance, protection, blessings, guidance, and everything needed for spiritual and physical well-being provided by God.

faqs.answer: This verse aligns with New Testament teachings about God's provision and faithfulness to believers through Jesus Christ. Just as God provided for Israel, He provides for Christians through His grace and the Holy Spirit.

faqs.answer: God being 'mindful' of His covenant highlights His commitment and faithfulness. It means He remembers and acts upon His promises, demonstrating His unwavering love and dedication to those in covenant relationship with Him.

faqs.answer: Apply this verse by cultivating reverence for God, trusting in His provision, remembering His promises during trials, and extending His grace to others through acts of kindness and service.
